title: The Replay (2/11/26): React performance wins, fine-grained frameworks, and more
partialText:
Discover what's new in The Replay, LogRocket's newsletter for dev and engineering leaders, in the February 11th issue.

The post The Replay (2/11/26): React performance wins, fine-grained frameworks, and more appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: A complete guide to React performance optimization
partialText:
Cut React LCP from 28s to ~1s with a four-phase framework covering bundle analysis, React optimizations, SSR, and asset/image tuning.

The post A complete guide to React performance optimization appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: 3 AI shockwaves reshaping product management in 2026
partialText:
How AI reshaped product management in 2025 and what PMs must rethink in 2026 to stay effective in a rapidly changing product landscape.

The post 3 AI shockwaves reshaping product management in 2026 appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: Fine Grained Everything, and what comes after React Server Components
partialText:
Rich Harris (creator of Svelte) joined PodRocket this week to unpack his Performance Now talk, Fine Grained Everything.

The post Fine Grained Everything, and what comes after React Server Components appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: Fortifying your stack with Cloudflare: A security playbook
partialText:
Cloudflare strengthens security at the edge, but real protection depends on how you design, layer, and own controls beyond it.

The post Fortifying your stack with Cloudflare: A security playbook appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: From custom integrations to A2UI: A better way to ship agent UIs
partialText:
AI agents don’t have to live in chat bubbles. This guide shows how A2UI lets agents generate real, interactive UIs, and walks through building a working React demo using Gemini and a2ui-bridge.

The post From custom integrations to A2UI: A better way to ship agent UIs appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: Linear vs. non-linear design: Which is better and when?
partialText:
There’s no universally “best” design language. This section breaks down when Linear-style design works well, how to build beyond it (or start from Radix UI), why it felt overused in SaaS marketing, and why conversion claims still need real testing.

The post Linear vs. non-linear design: Which is better and when? appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: LaunchPod: Using AI to Preserve 140 Years of History at the LA Times
partialText:
Deepika Manglani, VP of Product at the LA Times, talks about how she’s bringing the 140-year-old institution into the future.

The post LaunchPod: Using AI to Preserve 140 Years of History at the LA Times appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: Linear design vs. minimalism, brutalism, and neumorphism
partialText:
Minimal doesn’t always mean usable. This comparison shows how Linear-style UI keeps contrast, affordances, and structure intact, unlike brutalism’s extremes or neumorphism’s low-clarity depth effects.

The post Linear design vs. minimalism, brutalism, and neumorphism appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: LLM routing in production: Choosing the right model for every request
partialText:
Learn how LLM routing works in production, when it’s worth the complexity, and how teams choose the right model for each request.

The post LLM routing in production: Choosing the right model for every request appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: How do you implement accessible linear design across light and dark modes?
partialText:
Linear-style UIs look simple, but the theming system has to do real work. Here’s how to meet WCAG 2.2 contrast requirements across light, dark, and high-contrast modes — whether you’re using a UI library or rolling your own tokens.

The post How do you implement accessible linear design across light and dark modes? appeared first on LogRocket Blog.

title: UX designers don’t need to be data scientists — but they must challenge data
partialText:
As product teams become more data-driven, UX designers are expected to connect design decisions to metrics. But real value comes from interpreting data, questioning assumptions, and bringing human behavior back into the conversation.

The post UX designers don’t need to be data scientists — but they must challenge data appeared first on LogRocket Blog.
